A note that is weird: It is surprisingly hard to actually fall into a black hole. This is for much the same reason as it is surprisingly hard to fall into the sun. Namely, if you are in orbit around a black hole, you have to expend a huge amount of energy to slow down enough to reach the center(or let the accretion disk do this for you), and if you are not in orbit of the black hole (which is unlikely), your best bet to getting there is to go into orbit first and then slow down.

This opens some very, very interesting angles of studying the black holes and especially their future or what someone might actually find after entering one (the concept of "white holes", the idea that black holes might actually "take us" to...other universes born out of their singularities or that we might actually exist inside of a...black hole). 🙂

The video is really good, the visuals always amaze me. However there are some errors in it, a few common misconceptions, that I thought would need addressing :

- 3:18 : this is only valid for a static observer, who uses rockets to stay motionless at a constant altitude (so an observer who experiences a very strong acceleration, which is actually what creates this fast-forward effect in their field of view). For a falling observer the passage of time in the outside universe would actually look slowed down, because of the Doppler effect. The observers falls away from the light of distant stars, and hence they receive it in increasingly slower motion.

- 4:31 : this is not correct. As a free falling observer, you would never have the impression of crossing the horizon, and the universe behind you will always take more than 50% of your field of view, even when you are technically inside the black hole. (See for example the simulations by Andrew J. S. Hamilton about falling into a Schwarzschild black hole) This is due to the effect of light aberration, caused by your very high speed. Actually, nothing special can be seen when you cross the horizon, you can't determine visually that you just crossed it, it's a fundamental principle due to the fact that the horizon is not a physical surface, and it doesn't exist locally (the horizon only makes sense on a global sense, at a large scale). And in particular you can still see the outside universe when you are inside the black hole, since the light from distant starts falls with you.

When i learned about black holes as a teenager I had a theory about what would happen if I stuck my hand in the event horizon and came to the conclusion my hand would stretch out and spaghettify. I'm astonished I got that idea correct, after seeing this several years later! I love space and physics so much as a teen I actually programmed a space simulation of planets on my texas instruments calculator. I managed to make two objects orbit around each other using Newton's laws of physics. I'm obsessed with how they work and I've watched countless hours of simulations. It's just heartwarming to see that all those things I imagined many years ago are in coordination with these theories here.

One thing I like to point out is that if these black holes shrink mass escapes the black hole. The black hole loses its size because of anti particles. Which means, the mass that escaped is a COMPLETELY new mass that never existed since the beginning of the universe. So after a incomprehensible amount of time I wonder if the Universe can be reborn again if the particles that were ejected pull each other back to a correlated center. I think if civilizations found out a way to enter and exit a black hole at the perfect time you could potentially see the second rebirth occur. If this new mass thing is true, that means it will be compliant to the fear of time paradox. Once you enter, the mass of you will slowly wither away because of anti-matter and the existence of your atoms will never be seen ever again. Because of this the fear of time paradox's will be null and void because no matter inside the black hole will get a chance to influence matter outside it. This is very good news because this means the Universe potentially will restart and stars can burn once again.

White holes are a different story, and I have to study that a lot more to understand what it could potentially do.

I believe that the greatest movie (so far) of the 21st century from a scientific standpoint is "Interstellar." I mean, if we were going to make a genuinely accurate movie poster for the movie, it would read "Starring: one MONSTROUS HUGE BLACK HOLE. Oh, and a few people. Here and there."

Never in history has a single movie so irrevocably changed the way how something so important to science is visualized. And what's more, visualized in a scientifically valid way. The creation of that black hole was driven by astronomy, physics, and other science. It wasn't designed by a design team looking to make a dramatic and interesting thing for the movie. The science designed it. They just created it to look exactly how science says it should look. That it turned out to be something so visually arresting was just pure good fortune. And yet, from now on for the rest of time that's how black holes are going to be depicted visually, or at least it's the clean-break starting point that may be elaborated on in the future as the science changes and our ability to turn theory into visuals advances. It's come a long way from just a big black spot surrounded by a vague ring-like structure as it was depicted in the past. When people actually even attempted to create a visual representation of something so huge, baffling, and powerful. None got it right until Interstellar.

And yeah, they created new science in the movie. That visual representation was written up in a peer-reviewed scientific paper that has been accepted and now is the "official" way black holes will be depicted forever more.

And I know I wasn't the only one...the damn thing wasn't just jaw-drop awe-inspiring. I found it menacing in the extreme. If I was a future spacefarer, I wouldn't want to go within a thousand light years of anything like that. Basically, if I could actually see the thing, that would mean I was too close. Time to turn around and head home.

A black hole is not a mass per se. It is a void created by the overlying mass of a galactic body. The black hole is in reality the epicenter of a rotating mass. If you examine a situation of say a thousand stars all rotaing about a common center. That central area becomes a void where no mass can enter that space due to the gravitational pull of each stars mass on that position. Electromagnetic radiation reaching that point would be diverted around the void toward its polar regions or its point of axis of rotation. All galaxies rotate about some axis direction. The radiation directed toward the void is thrown out at its poles as streams of high intensity Gamma Radiation. Every multiple body situation which is in a rotational aspect creates a point mas center of a non-mass void, however, small. Sometimes this void is contained within one of the masses based on the mass of each of the contributors. This is the case between Earth and our Moon.

There are two meanings for the word time. The psychological meaning for the word “time” is:  Time is the order of change.  The physical meaning for the word “time” is: Time is the movement of the universe through the 4th-dimension of space-time. When space-time is curved because of mass some of the motion of the universe through the 4th-dimension is diverted into the three spacial dimensions of the universe. That motion pushes the distance separating massive objects away. This push is what we call gravity. Gravity does not move objects it moves the universe.

Hey, I love your vids, just discovered them recently and have been binge watching, so great job guys!

That being said, if I may, I do have one question that I would like to ask/have-clarified please. And this is a legit, please-educate-me question! :-)

08:45 According to my limited understanding of Hawking Radiation, quantum particles are born from nothing (in essence) because when they are born, each fluctuation produces one particle of matter (+1) and one particle of anti-matter (-1), thus when they recombine they = 0 and both cease to exist, as you so awesomely stated.

However, at 09:10, you stipulate that Hawking radiation is "new stuff, stealing mass from [the black hole]".

My question is that (again, according to my extremely limited understanding) nothing is stolen from a black hole, but rather the quantum radiation creates a particle or matter (+1) that escapes the event horizon, as well as one particle of anti-matter (-1) that is sucked into the black hole, and annihilates from existence the first particle of matter it touches.

Yes, the math is the same, whether the particle of hawking radiation "steals" the mass from a black hole, or whether the particle of mass is simply created and the resulting particle of anti-matter obliterates a particle of matter from the black hole, over all, the black hole is -1 particle of matter from the ordeal, HOWEVER, I don't agree with (and thus obviously don't properly understand) that black holes would thus ONLY shrink and die over time from a bombardment of 10^100x anti-matter (-1) particles.

Because (unless ONLY anti-matter particles are affected by the gravity at an event horizon) roughly half (50%, statically speaking due to the fact that only one of two possibilities can occur) of the quantum fluctuations would result in either the particle of anti-matter (-1) being sucked in (as previously outlined) OR, if the orientation of the initial fluctuation split is reversed, a particle of matter (+1) would get sucked in, resulting in the black hole GAINING a particle of matter and the resultant particle of anti-matter would drift off into space until it randomly crashed into a passing comet (or whatever), annihilating one particle of matter in our spacetime, resulting in the black hole increasing in size by one particle of matter instead of shrinking.

So my argument would be (again, everything statistically speaking) that either the black hole would remain the same size from exactly 50% of all hawking radiation fluctuations falling on both sides of the bell curve of matter (+1) or anti-matter (-1) being sucked in, OR the other argument is that some offset from the 50% would occur in which 50%+X% of the anti-matter particles get sucked in resulting in a smaller black hole, but that would theoretically be balanced out from another statistically mated black hole where 50%-X% of anti-matter particles get sucked in, resulting in a bigger black hole.


Thank you for your time with this question! :-)

This is my theory of what a black hole is.
A black hole's event horizon is really the surface. Since the gravity is so strong the light or whatever can't escape the surface; meaning that you can't see what's happening but what really is happening is that whatever gets too close just gets crushed at speeds so high that there's little change to the surface. Also since the gravity is so strong the surface has been crushed down so hard that it is almost perfectly smoothe. Basically a black hole is made of stones, metals, light itself, gasses, liquid if it can exist. But that's my theory of what a black hole is.

I have an idea : that when mass and space cannot be subdivided or minimised any further, as what we see In black holes, that energy must go into what we would consider mathematically as “negative”. Ie -1, -0.1, -2.222/square of 3
Large constituents of this break our understanding of physics and are not currently reconciled. However smaller examples such as primordial black holes, as matter, gravitational, and time inequalities, are prolific and unobservable, yet influence the galactic scale and beyond phenomena that we currently are perplexed by.

Are you done? Because the Hawking radiation is a lot weirder than you describe. The inward falling anti-partner has mass-energy, so when it falls in it adds to the BH mass. The reason Hawking evaporation reduces the BH mass is because of the screwing up of time --- the "infalling" anti-partner is a negative frequency mode (hence negative energy) and can be a photon, so not necessarily anti-matter, so it is actually coming out of the BH from our clock's point of view (if we were only able to view it from our frame of ref, which we can't).   This is at least one field-theoretic way of describing the Hawking radiation more precisely, there are other complementary descriptions.

It's suddenly extremely depressing realizing that space is so infinitely vast and complex that, no matter what happens, human society will never be around long enough to properly observe it all. Even if we overcame climate change or politics, and became a star trek-esque, post-scarcity society of star explorers and expanded throughout the galaxy, the odds of any scientist witnessing the death of a black hole before all of humanity dies out for some reason or another are cosmically slim.

There are aliens out there, somewhere, simply through sheer odds: No matter the explanation, life formed on our planet somehow, so therefor it is in fact possible, and space is so infinitely vast that it has happened again somewhere else, probably a nearly infinite number of times. And there is definitely intelligent life out there too by the same reason: anything that has happened at least once has the potential to happen again. But even if it did, there's so much potential space out there, that the odds of us meeting any other life, let alone something as specific as life that is intelligent in ways that we can understand and relate to, is also cosmically low. This isn't even an individual matter: I'm not sad that we won't make contact with aliens in my lifetime, I'm sad that there's good odds that no humans will ever make that contact.
If we're real lucky, it'll turn out that there's aliens in our solar system somewhere that we just couldn't observe with modern technology. But they'll almost certainly be non-intelligent

Actually it's really easy to understand 10^100 years. Because there are within 20% of 10^50 atoms in planet Earth. So just imagine 2 planet Earths. Every year, one atom is taken away from the Earth on the left. When it's gone, it is reconstructed and one single atom is removed from the Earth on the right. And again, the Earth on the left is deconstructed one atom per year, and when it's gone again, a 2nd atom is removed from the Earth on the right. This process is repeated, and 10^100 years is about the time it takes for the Earth on the right to disappear. Or for 10^67 years, just consider 10^17 years for every atom in the Earth, that's 100 quadrillion years or 10 million times the current age of the universe, for each atom in Earth. That's how long it takes for a solar mass black hole to evaporate. See? It's not hard to imagine at all. Incidentally, vacuum decay would most certainly be set off by the evaporation of any black hole to the very end, as that would be the point at which it would reach the planck temperature, and if that isn't enough energy to push that region of space over the threshold, nothing is, so you'd better hope there aren't any primordial black holes just about to finish evaporating anywhere in the universe, because that could happen at any time, and if it did, you could be gone before you even finish reading th

“An eon is long, monk. It is not easy to count it and say it is so many years, or so many hundreds of years, or so many thousands of years, or so many hundreds of thousands of years.”

“It is possible, monk,” the Blessed One said. “Suppose, monk, there was a great stone mountain a yojana long, a yojana wide, and a yojana high, without holes or crevices, one solid mass of rock. 8:46 It actually is a particle with positive mass and an "antiparticle" with equal but negative mass. When they "annihilate", they disappear completely. By contrast when a particle meets its "antimatter antiparticle" (which is the same particle but with opposite charge), they turn into 2 photons of light upon annihilation.

Which makes me wonder why only the "particles" escape and the "antiparticles" get swallowed when it shall be opposite - the black hole should be growing while spitting out megatons of matter with negative mass (because negative mass is repelled by gravity). Most likely this "virtual particles" are actually only a very inaccurate description and what actually is happening is that the content of the black hole is somehow tunneling through the event horizon back to our universe. Or the "negative mass" is somehow attracted to the black hole's event horizon with a force much stronger than the "positive mass" because the negative mass "mistakes" the black hole for its "positive mass partner" due to quantum effect distortion due to the event horizon.

Well, or energy. In general relativity mass and energy is more or less the same thing and the various particles differ only in some sort of "internal organization" of said energy or something ...

You will definitely not survive to see the inside of the black hole even when it is as big as an entire galaxy. The problem is that when you are at a certain distance from the event horizon (still outside), the matter of your body will get smashed into a blob of super-heated quark-gluon plasma by the extremely blue-shifted cosmic background radiation and starlight (not to mention the occasional matter particle which (due to the released gravitational potential) will now weight as much as a small star (or even more).

One minor correction, when you say the particles formed during hawking radiation form "out of nothing", that's not accurate. They form from quantum field fluctuations, and one way to think of them is as manifestations of the quantum field. If we were to assert that the particles formed from actual nothing, we would have to assert that a thing which exists was created from that which cannot exist. This is because actual "nothing" has no attributes, no space, no energy, and is defined apart from "thing"/"being", or that which actually exists. If we wish to hold to this, we would have to hold a completely contradictory and absurd view, which is why we use "fields" in the first place. Just as electro-magnetic force cannot move through that which does not exist to affect object, so too can particles not actually be generated from literal nothing.

If you are using "nothing" in a different way, I would appreciate the clarification, maybe a different wording set of words to understand what you are trying to get across.

When they talk about something trying to escape a black hole, they’re talking about some object with a certain amount of kinetic energy trying to use that energy to escape the black hole. But no matter how high that kinetic energy is, it’s not enough to escape the black hole. But there are two ways for a rocket to escape earth’s gravity. One is for it to give itself enough kinetic energy that the kinetic energy exceeds the energy required to escape. The other way is for it to blast its engines continuously, maybe at a very slow rate but strong enough to make progress, and keep going and going and going until finally it gets far enough away that the gravity gets small enough that it escapes. Now, no rocket works that way because it would take an incredible amount of energy to escape that way, it’s far easier and less energy consuming to just build up enough kinetic energy. But if you can’t build up enough kinetic energy, as in the case of a black hole, then that alternative method, why wouldn’t it work?

Let’s look at it a different way. Suppose you stay well away from the black hole and you lower somebody down into it on a rope, a very strong rope or cable. Once they’re down inside, past the black hole event horizon, you start pulling them back up. Why couldn’t you pull them out? Could you?

Why black holes are call black holes?
Why black holes are usually illustrated as a disc with a certain diameter?

That makes no sense at all!

Black holes are one or more stars, which are 3-dimensional objects, collapsed in itself, which is still a 3-dimensional object, only a lot denser than the stars were before collapsing.

The black holes are as much a sphere as the original star, only smaller and denser.

The event horizon is not around a disc but around a sphere.

Space is not warped downwards but around the sphere in all 3 dimensions of space.

A black hole is not a hole in space to somewhere else. It’s matter so dense that space is warped around it.

To me calling it black stars instead of black holes would make a lot more sense.

I've just watched this video with a physicist friend and we have three questions.

1- How can the black holes generate their electric charge? If they are composed of "black hole matter" they shouldn't have it, or they should all have a charge proportional to their masses, and if it is due to charged particles they swallow, the electromagnetic field propagates as a wave at the speed of light, so it should not be able to go outside of the event horizon, should it?

2 - why the hawking radiation removes mass from the black hole? As I understand, it is in fact swallowing one particle, and gaining one particle of mass, not loosing it.

3 - this one is a thought experiment. If I had a very long rope, and I go near to a black hole and release the rope, so one extreme crosses the event horizon while I hold the other extreme (let's suppose I have an spaceship with enough power to keep me at a fixed distance of the black hole), what would happen? Would I be pulled into the black hole by the rope no matter what? Would the rope mechanically break due to the tension, with a piece falling inside and I keeping the other? Or once a particle of the rope crosses the event horizon it looses its bound to the rest of the rope and just falls on its own?

Sorry for the long comment and the amount of questions and thank you for such amazing videos ❤

I watch every video I can find on Black Holes, but can't seem to find a detailed answer on this... Do we know for certain that Black Holes have a Singularity? In the sense that everything is at a single point with 0 Dimensions. It is possible that it is a physical sphere that exists in 3 Dimensions like a Neutron star but more densely packed (say a Quark star)? Mathematics and logic would suggest that it must have a true physical size and not a single point with no dimensions (division by zero is illogical to even state as an equation, it not only has no answer but has no reason to ever be asked). Say a Neutron star of 10KM that has an escape velocity of 50% the speed of light, what if it compacts to 5KM as a Quark Star (or some other sub-Neutron sized particle) with an escape velocity of equal / greater than the speed of light so we cannot see it and would "think" we are looking at a Black Hole but if we could it would still be a sphere, just more Dense (I know that math isn't perfect, just creating a concept)... why do we default to an idea that it has 0 physical size? Do we really know for sure this isn't the case? Maybe a different sub-atomic particle that we have or haven't yet discovered is the true "crunch limit" of matter and the stuff Black Holes are made of. I've heard before about Singularities that (they are not real, just a placeholder explanation for what we cannot yet explain like saying "Magic" in the middle ages for events that we could not explain via science at the time). If it truly is a point of 0 Dimensions than it would not matter at all how much mass the Black Hole is made of, all of them would have identical event horrizon radii. 20/0 vs 10/0 does not give two different answers, the fact that larger mass Black Holes have larger event horrizons I would think would confirm the physical size idea, did I explain this concept well?

I'm assuming we use infinity to describe the density of a black hole because we aren't currently able to measure how crushed particles can really get. If we really knew what the smallest particles were, we'd probably be able to measure approximately how dense a black hole is. Right as a sun turns into a black hole if you could measure the size of the singularity you'd be able to determine it's real density based on the size and density of the star it used to be. To say it's infinitely dense is to say it doesn't have size, but rather it exists in a state of shrinking infinitely.

Matter cannot be infinitely dense, as density is the measurement of how tight particles are, eventually they'd stop somewhere or else particles inside black holes would be crushing into smaller and smaller particles infinitely at infinite speed, to say they are infinitely dense is to say that particles can become infinitely small, none of this sets right with mathematics.

TL;DR I theorize that there 'is' a limit to the density of black holes, we just don't know what that is because it defies our current measurement capabilities.

the 3 main theories are heat death, the big rip, and the big crunch. right now, people say that heat death is "the most likely" according to our currently KNOWN laws of physics. but that's because there's so much we don't know for certain. so what if the end of the universe is a compromise between the big rip and the big crunch?

the big rip theorizes that the universe ends when dark energy becomes stronger than gravity, dissolving everything into its components. if dark energy only gets stronger over time, then by the time it's ripped apart every other piece of matter in the universe only black holes will be left—the strongest forces of gravity in the universe. what happens when a black hole is ripped apart before hawking radiation kills it? what happens when you cross the threshold that traps infinite information at an infinite density? my guess: a lights show. an explosion so powerful that a new universe starts pushing against the borders of the one it's already in; an expanding bubble that effectively resets the battle against dark energy.

to that end: what if the universe IS restarting over and over, but multiplying and getting smaller each time? every time a black hole loses the battle against dark energy, a new universe forms and creates another bubble universe? idk this idea is just fascinating to me even if its wrong and this video has me thinking

Great animations, but there are a few things in this video that are simply wrong:
1.) Singularities probably don't exist, and it isn't clear that there's any reason they have to to be consistent with physics. The curvature doesn't need to be infinite to form an event horizon
2.) There is memory of the constituent parts that make up a black hole "singularity": Hawking proved that that information would be inscribed on the surface of the black hole, just like the persistent after-image of someone falling in would be. It would break the second law of thermodynamics for that to not be the case
3.) Black holes explode into the leftover matter not radiated away during their lifetime AS WELL AS a lot of light and exotic particles. There is certainly something left after their passing

Oh come on. Time travel just because their gravity so high? Time is a constant. And what we see in space is just the past. If we travel faster than light, sure it might feel like you travel through the future, but really you're just going through that which you've seen which has already happened. The present is what matters and the present is the truth. A black hole 'bends time' because it bends light. If you were to get that close as you suggested in the video, the past light particles coming from, let's say Earth, are just getting bent while you're in there. But time itself ain't changing. Only what you see is changing. It's like if we could travel in the speed of light, the Earth behind us the the ship we're using will look like it's standing still. But it's not. It's rotating and clouds are still moving. It's just because we don't see the reflected light particles from the Earth. While it looks like time will stand still, we would actually move 'back in time' in reference to the Earth, but stuffs still happening constantly, and that constant is the present which we can't see clearly when moving that fast.

Please stop propagating the incorrect analogy of Hawking Radiation. In reality, what’s happening is that the curved space around the black hole is constantly emitting radiation due to the curvature gradient around it, and that the energy is coming from the black hole itself, causing its event horizon to slowly shrink over time.

Black holes are not decaying because there’s an infalling virtual particle carrying negative energy; that’s another fantasy devised by Hawking to “save” his insufficient analogy. Instead, black holes are decaying, and losing mass over time, because the energy emitted by this Hawking radiation is slowly reducing the curvature of space in that region.

Please stop spreading this all too common misunderstanding. 🤦‍♂️

I love your videos but this one is missing a key point that I feel you should address in a new video. Namely, the information paradox that they seemed to present, by removing the entropy/information of the particles that they suck in. The most likely explanation at the moment, to my understanding, is that black holes end up storing all of that information and entropy. Information is not erased, it can't be. This last point is as fundamental as the conservation of momentum or conservation of energy. In fact, it's intimately tied to these.

In short, it's extremely likely that black holes do not erase information of things that fall in. That part is wrong, to the best of our collective understanding.

5:14 This is really the important sentence, and it's why black holes are black holes — why everything falls inward. The start of the video makes it seem like gravitational potential wells are responsible, which is misleading as it's applying an inherently Newtonian concept to an inherently relativistic object.

Also, 8:36 This explanation of Hawking radiation was just something that Hawking came up with so he'd have an explanation for lay people — it has very little in common with the actual explanation, which has a lot more to do with the Unruh effect, where accelerated frames measure different particle numbers from non-accelerated frames. ScienceAsylum has a reasonably accurate video on it.

If the black hole is large enough, not spinning, and without an accretion disk you might actually surivive up til the moment you cross the event horizon. At least I don't know any other factors that would kill you before then. The problem of course, is that once you cross that border there is only one direction that's possible to move in, which would mean that your body (or any other form of matter) instantly desintegrate, because electromagnetism presumably work due to virtual photons acting as carrying particles that bind atoms and molecules together, and the strong nuclear force works on a similar principle. Those carrying particles needs to move backwards and forwards to communicate between the elementary particles that form matter, which would be impossible within a black hole. It may be able to move forwards, but there is no backwards. Thus all the forces we know about instantly ceases to affect reality, and any matter that slip inside presumably becomes a slur of elementary particles heading for the singularity. A singularity it will never reach, of course, because the closer it gets the more time will slow down for it. It's like Zeno's paradox. One can get very close to the singularity, but it would literally take infinite time to actually reach it from an outside perspective. That means the black hole will have vaporized from hawking radiation an infinite amount of time before anything could actually reach the singularity, including the stuff that originally created the black hole, so really, there is no singularity.

I recently changed jobs. I learned that a female supervisor at my workplace suffered from many ailments that the hospital could not treat. Despite spending nearly a thousand yuan, she still had difficulty breathing.

Since I had just begun working there, I was not on close terms with anyone, so I asked a practitioner who was hired before me to suggest that the supervisor say, “Falun Dafa is good, Truthfulness-Compassion-Forbearance is good.” The practitioner did. The supervisor asked me, “Will reciting the phrase help me?” I said, “As long as you do it sincerely, it will work.” It was time to go home. She locked the door and then shouted loudly, “Falun Dafa is good! Truthfulness, Compassion, Forbearance is good!”

The next day, she shouted “Falun Dafa is good!” as soon as she saw me and the other practitioner.

A few days later she told us she was able to breathe easily. There was a growth on her neck that had been plaguing her for six years, and the pain made her irritable. She said excitedly, “Since I started to recite the phrase, the growth subsided. How extraordinary!”

The other workers commented that she looked healthier. She said to them, “Why don’t you all say “Falun Dafa is good.” It truly works! Just keep saying it and you’ll see the results.”

“I recite it while I am driving, before going to bed, and the first thing when I wake up in the morning,” she added.

Now, when she sees me, she recites the phrase loudly. I was worried that the manager upstairs would hear it and I was amazed by her courage. She told me that she once shouted the phrase out loud while driving around on her electric bike since she was alone. Suddenly, a man who was also driving an electric bike pulled alongside her and looked at her. She asked, “What are you looking at?” and then shouted, “Falun Dafa is good!” This took a lot of courage!

Under her influence, my colleagues at work began to recite the phrase as well. Even the manager kept saying the words. Not only did they quit the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), they even got their family members to renounce their Party memberships.

One day the supervisor said, “My husband said, ‘You seem to have changed.’” She asked her husband, “How have I changed?” He said, “You are kinder. You don’t throw a temper anymore.” She said she used to be a domineering woman. No one at home dared to upset her. She explained that after she started to sincerely recite, “Falun Dafa is good,” she stopped losing her temper and she became kinder. She credits Falun Dafa for her positive change.

Your animation of the black hole at 0:00, 10:30, and elsewhere has the rotation going the wrong way on the bottom of the image.

The material that goes around the black hole is similar to material that goes around Saturn. It's a ring of material that goes around the black hole in a single direction. But the reason why it is usually animated so that you can see the rotating material from the top and bottom of the black hole as well is because the light is bent. What you are seeing is the rotating material from the other side of the black hole. But instead of it being obscured by the black hole, you can see it from the bent light waves that go above and below the black hole.

This means that if the material is rotating horizontally from right to left in front of the black hole, as you show it at 10:30, then the image of the rotation that you see on the top and bottom of the black hole must move from left to right. You animated this properly on the top part, but not the bottom part, which you erroneously made flow from right to left.

To better understand this, it may be helpful to realize that the part of the rotating disc that is on the other side of the black hole is visible twice here: on the top and on the bottom. These are not two different flows; it's the same flow. If you threw a planet to the right side of that black hole and watched it orbit, you'd see the planet move in front of the black hole from the right side to the left side. Then, when it hits the far left side, you'd see TWO DIFFERENT VIEWS of the planet on both the top and bottom side of the black hole. Keep in mind that the planet is not actually on the top and bottom; it's just on the far side. But because light is bent, we see the planet on both the top and bottom rings, moving from left to right.

Relativity only explains the measurements between individual perspectives, it's not an actual law of nature/reality. From how I understand it, to say that the newly created particle steals mass from the black hole wouldn't be accurate, as that's not possible. What should actually happen, is that the anti-particle that doesn't escape the event horizon would annihilate an equivalent amount of mass within the singularity/ringularity, keeping to the law of conservation of energy.
That is assuming that this event really happens, black holes exist, and enough particles escape their corresponding anti-particles to make a difference, especially if you take into account that the exact opposite could happen, adding mas to the black hole and sending anti-matter out into the universe. But, I'm no physicist, so I canne be certain. (Feel free to politely tell me your thoughts if you wish.)

The breakdown of mathematic understanding, to me, suggests that this is a rare case where the current math concerning the concept is in all respects less useful than the functional, practical explanation of how singularities function. As this video demonstrates, the overall concept of a singularity can be explained in practical terms easily, with the main problems coming into play when regarding complications like a surface area of zero and other absurdities. All jokes about never needing advanced mathematics in real life aside, most higher-level math and physics equations do have an intrinsic value beyond any immediate utility, in that they generally provide additional elaboration that can help better understand the behavior of something already reasonably well-understood elementary-level math or description in laymans terms.

The division by zero metaphor is apt regarding this concept, albeit not perfect. For most cases, the elementary explanations for why division by zero are invalid, notably "division as inversion of multiplication" and the potential for fallacious results from attempting to reverse multiplication by zero, do not seem to benefit much from elaboration via higher-level math. The very noteworthy exception, and the reason I said it's not a perfect comparison, is that higher-level mathematics does provide a fleshing out of why dividing zero by zero is also not allowed, when at first glance it would make perfect sense for zero divided by zero to equal zero. And it does so in a way that uses, and fleshes out, the second elementary-level explanation by which division by zero could hypothetically return any result if permitted.

That's a misunderstanding. The singularity isn't the "point" at a center of a black hole, then it wouldn't be a singularity, it would be a place. The entire gravitational field is the singularity, a theoretical number that never equals zero sum, distance, in this case. It surely gets smaller and smaller, and gets more and more point-like, but as our understanding is, there is no center to get to. It's "moving" away faster than anything can possibly catch it.

A lot of people and sadly this explains it as the point in the center that just sits there... singularity being some kind of object. But it's not a place that is ever reachable, so it really shouldn't be described as a place not without explanation, it's misleading.

I don't imagine we would feel or even notice a change if we fell into a black hole. Yes, the spacetime around us would be spaghettified and shrunk into an infinitely small point with us inside. However, we are unable to feel any changes or ripples to the spacetime that we are in. We have made laboratories that have successfully detected gravity waves traveling through our spacetime. These gravity waves are a compression and decompression of our spacetime that cannot be felt by us. It is only detectable by comparing changes made in two identical light waves. Since we cannot feel the compression and decompression of spacetime, we would probably be unable to feel the compression of spacetime inside of a black hole. Inside of the black hole as spacetime compresses all matter and empty space to an infinitely small point, there would an infinite amount of space. I imagine it would actually seem as though everything is expanding away from us as we all shrink. We probably already are in a black hole.

A black hole's singularity (or a ring-singularity, aka a "ringularity" in spinning black holes) is precisely like a divide-by-zero error. The curvature of space-time at an event horizon is literally a 3-Dimensional asymptote. Hypothetically it would be possible to enter and exit a black hole's event horizon using an Alcubierre Drive (aka a Frame Shift Drive or Hyper-drive), as it could allow a space-bourn vessel to travel at superluminal speeds; however, from the perspective of the pilot it could possibly allow more light (and more of space by extension) to be seen, which would make the event horizon appear to shrink. If the event horizon shrinks while traveling at superluminal speeds, you would have to travel infinitely fast for the event horizon to fully disappear, still making it impossible to even cross into it in the first place. This is completely hypothetical, but that would be my prediction.

You are saved by God’s grace, through faith alone, in Christ alone.

The Bible says, "For all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God" (Romans 3:23)

The Bible also says, "For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord. " (Romans 6:23)

2000 years ago, God sent His only begotten Son Jesus Christ down to this earth. Jesus Christ was a perfect and sinless God-Man, and the only sacrifice God counted as worthy to take our sin punishment away (which would be hell). Jesus died on the cross, was buried, and rose from the dead!

Right now, you can be saved from the damnation of hell because Jesus Christ paid the fine for you by giving His life on the cross at Calvary.

I am sceptical about the "time" part in the video, mostly because time is just a measurement "we" use, to map how "long" we've been alive, people before us, and how fast the "deteroration" of our biomass have gotten. I mean "reactions" like how oxygen and our lungs interact isn't decided by "time" like how fast water is absorbed etc. it's all reactions either way, so time is such a weird thing to use.

Unless in the video you meant that "time is halted" as in reactions, or interactions and things that would deteriorate (or atoms that would interact) aren't allowed to do so. In that instance I can believe the whole "time stands still" or "time travel is possible" but time travel isn't possible, unless we can reverse-engineer biomass and our bodies and every actions we've done, like reverse do everything we've done, but that's such a weird up in the air concept. I know some believe in "time travel" but I'm way too logical for that to really sound plausible, since it isn't represented in any of the atoms, reactions or scientific things we know.

In as simple way as possible to describe it.

Everything that does not have a force applied to it, moves in a straight line.
Gravity bends straight lines into curves.
Blackholes curve all straight lines within the event horizon to point towards their center of that black hole.

So even if you look away from the center of the blackhole and try to move towards it, you are actually still moving towards the center.

Good video.
I do however think the Hawking Radiation explanation was over-simplified and could potentially do with its own video. (The effect has nothing to do with matter/anti-matter particle pairs)
No matter actually enters or leaves the black hole as a result of the virtual particles (actually pairs of virtual photons), but rather it is mediated with a "partner wave" created by gravity acting on one of the virtual photons that then imparts negative energy to the black hole, the escaping photon then adds positive energy to the rest of the universe. This allows the the black hole to exhibit the predicted black-body radiation and have an effective temperature.
[The other topic which gets pop-sci over simplified to the point of meaningless is the Higgs-Field, and that could definitely do with its own video explaining it "properly".]

So the moment a massive Star dies and its matter implodes, shouldn't it experience the same phenomenom as a person entering the eventhorizon later? For the observer from the outside it may look like there is a black hole now and it lasts a long time before evaporating. But for the original matter time is different. So the collapsing mass from the star is still imploding, but while crushing into itself, time "slows down" to a point where it looks from the outside like it stopped collapsing. At this point, hawking radiation from the outside may take almost an infinite amount of time, but it's still faster than the matter collapsing inside.
The orignal implosion of the matter from the star evaporates through hawking radiation before it reaches the infinite dense point of a singularity because of the different perspectives of time.
From a viewpoint of the center of the original star it should look like an explosion that collapses into itself and before reaching the singularity state, evaporates into nothing.

Being scientific and all, it's worth mentioning that infinity is a mathematical concept, not a physical one. It doesn't really exist. Meaning that a point "infinitely small" is a misconception. Which I think is far less confusing, if not misleading, to claim for physical infinities.

We keep hearing how the universe kind of restarts every eternity or so, and if thats true, I think black holes are the beginning and end of that cycle.
Stars bleed energy in the form of heat over time, and the same is true for planets. Stars are supported on their radiation, pushing against gravity. We are pretty certain that gravity always ends up winning in the end.
Black holes consume anything that passes too close, and their field of influence grows whenever that happens. Everything is focused to a single point inside.
Planets like earth orbit the sun, but its really a stupidly slow spiral. Earth will eventually fall into the sun if left alone. If planets do this with regular stars, then galaxies are kind of just massive systems, all spinning and spiraling to their center, where there are damn near always Black holes (if not always. I dont know for sure).
This video mentions how anything within a certain range of a Black hole is forced to orbit it, a cascading spiral. It also mentions how a you get closer to a Black hole, any motion you make in any direction will always lead to the center. Consider that, but scale it up. Dramatically.

If orbits are cascading spirals, and galaxies are huge clusters of celestial bodies orbiting around Black holes, then eventually everything will be consumed. Galaxies are moving away from each other, but how large would the influence of a galaxy sized Black hole be? And galaxies do occasionally collide, but giant black holes would just consume each other, instead of galaxies shedding apart. And if their fields gets big enough, then the motion of moving apart may draw them together.
These multi galaxy sized singularities will have unimaginably large egregious spheres, yanking everything around them into their orbit, including other galaxy sized Black holes. Rinse and repeat, and after an eternity or so, you would end up with only a few Black holes containing all the mass of the known universe. Eventually only one will remain, having consumed everything else.

A single point, but now containing all matter, with properties similar to that of fundamental particles, like quarks, acting more like many electrons. That sounds pretty similar what the beginning of our universe looked like, and we don't know how it got that way, and we don't really know what happened in the very beginning. Physics can't explain it. Physics also can't explain what is happening in Black holes.

I guess this is my YouTube thesis? Sources are this channel, vsauce, Dan the science man, and various scientists and peoples talking about Black holes. And me.

Actually Hawking Radiation is not due to virtual particles coming into existence near the Event Horizon. It's coming from a large region of particle filled space outside the Event Horizon due to the distortion of the Quantum Field, making some of the wave modes unavailable. Normally the wave modes are canceling each other out in empty space, but near a Black Hole not.

The middle of this video actually makes no sense.

If everything which is consumed by a black hole was to be super compressed at it's singularity... that would mean there'd be an infinitely large super star on the other side of the singularity... you know, because matter can never be created nor destroyed.

So with the rule of conservation saying mass cannot be destroyed, the matter being swallowed up by the black hole must go somewhere... and the idea of a super star on the other side would also be unrealistic. On the contrary, the most plausible option would be that the matter is ejected on the other side to either begin a new cycle, or it would merely not be noticeable in the known universe for billions of years, until enough time has passed for every living thing outside the event horizon.

Purely speaking on the basis that because of time dilation within the event horizon, anything inside would basically be stuck in a state of motionless stasis, as far as we as observers would be able to actually observe. Obviously, it's not motionless though, so at some point in the far future, the matter would once again be in play.

One could even argue... a black hole actually creates a parallel universe which is already set in the far future, coexisting side by side with our current... because inside the event horizon, little to no time has passed at all between it opening up and collapsing.

But in the end, yeah, the idea that the matter just purely disappears into nothingness, just doesn't match up with other scientific theories, and the follow up remark that singularities might not even exist seems to be the most plausible option of all. Add to that the electronic charge of the matter which would have built up on every single atom within the black hole due to it's infinitesimal speed, those atoms would shoot out of the other side like a bullet on mega steroids... eventually colliding with something else and creating something new.

From this, we can also assume the universe as a whole entity can never cease to exist, and all videos suggesting that it can, also have no basis... because they also assume that the matter will ultimately cease to exist... which as said above, isn't possible based on current theory.

You can't fall into a black hole. Nothing can. By the time you reached the event horizon, time dilation would be so extreme that the entire history of the universe would play out before your eyes in an instant, and the black hole would evaporate away beneath you over those unfathomably long aeons that just blipped past. The reason nothing can "escape" from a black hole is that the direction toward the center of the black hole is the direction "toward the future", and nothing can come back in time; everything falling toward a black hole does eventually emerge, just unfathomably long in the future.

Despite all the research and time spent studying astrophysics.. I still don't believe in black holes, at least not as they're commonly described.
I don't believe it's a "singularity", *no where else in the universe* have we ever observed "infinity". There's even a minimum fraction of time, plank time.. There's a minimum unit of distance, plank length. In mathematics, if your equation results in an infinity, it's a sign you've made a blunder in your calculations.
I believe black holes are actually just neutron stars that've acquired enough mass that their gravitational pull exceeds the speed of light at a distance that exceeds the radius of the body.. Conversely this could also imply that there are black holes inside neutron stars. Basically the same exact thing as a "black hole", but no singularity-- just a neutron star. There's a theory that mostly aligns with the above, can research "dark stars" if you're interested in it.

Though I want to ask about a couple of things that weren't mentioned.

First, even in a super massive black hole, I think the delta gravity would be extreme enough to crush you one piece at a time, even if you didn't spagettify. To the best of my understanding, gravity works like pressure, where it is applied on all your molecules and cells individually, rather than treating you as a single rigid body. You'd be just one supermassive molecule. Either you'd be crushed, or ripped piece by piece even without the radius being small, just because of the gravity gradient.

Second, what is the stuff that comes out the top and bottom of the ergosphere? Small correction at 3:21 "...while you watch the universe above you speed up." Actually the universe would ALSO appear to slow down to you as you look outward when falling into the black hole. The universe will seem to slow down and rush away from you at close to the speed of light. (I.e., relative to YOU the rest of the universe will be moving at close to light speeds AWAY from you, as you appear to rush away from the rest of the universe from it's perspective.)
If there was some SURFACE to stand on at the event horizon this would push up on your feet (the same way the ground pushes up on your feet on Earth). This would then reverse your acceleration vector and THEN time would appear to speed up as you looked out at the universe. (This is the same reason why when you get in a ship and travel away from the black hole you will go far into the future.)

8:35 I really, really hate the heuristic "pair particle" explanation of Hawking radiation being used as if it were factual. It's a knowingly false explanation given to make it sound simple when it's not.

Virtual particle pair production wouldn't change the mass of the black hole. Antiparticles annihilating with particles releases the energy equivalent of its mass - so the mass does not go down. In the bad explanation that is this heuristic explanation, you're imagining that only the antiparticles are being pulled in, which would add to the mass because it's adding to the energy. Actual pair production at the event horizon is random, so the net change is zero.

What's actually occurring is Unruh effect. From the perspective of the outside universe, the event horizon is an acceleration horizon, which in turn means that from the frame of reference of the outside universe, the quantum vacuum energy state is radiant energy - Hawking radiation. From the perspective inside the event horizon, this perspective is reversed, gradually reducing the mass of the black hole. Yes, the Unruh effect is really hard to get your head around, but unlike pair production, it actually works to evaporate a black hole...

Its a fun reminder that the actual "black" part of a black hole is not a tangible or physical thing. Its the absence of light, so its actually just a massive shadow that's spherical because the gravity in the center is so strong. And since gravity attracts, it makes sense why it would be a sphere, kinda like how all celestial bodies are spherical.

(Side note, I know its probably made obvious given the folks who watch these videos but I thought it would be fun to try and explain this in a simple way)

For anybody interested in a more... accurate explanation of Hawking radiation, the universe can be understood as being ubiquitously permeated with quantum fields. These quantum fields correspond to particles. There's an electron field, a field for each quark, etc. Particles exist as a particularly high fluctuation in the energy of this field and can be described as a wave propagating on the field. What a black hole does to spacetime is catastrophic to these fields, pinching them off and disconnecting two previously continuous points on that field. That changes the way the field can behave, and that change is a kind of work that the black hole does on the fields.

A big problem with the virtual-particle explanation of a black hole is that we would expect the absolute energy loss of a black hole to be proportional to its surface area. This is not the case. The black hole actually releases a much much much greater amount of energy right at the end of its life, when its surface area is very very very very small, and there's a straightforward reason for this when we think of the quantum fields. A smaller surface with more apparent curvature will cause more problems for the field than a really really really big surface that operates on those fields the way electric field lines operate in a parallel plate capacitor.

Just an interesting thing to add: for an observer who has crossed the event horizon, the BH singularity is actually a moment in time, rather than a place in space. This is because black holes mess up spacetime so much that in a sense, what is time for someone outside the BH becomes space to someone inside and vice-versa. So once you cross the event horizon, you cannot avoid the BH singularity, as you cannot avoid the coming of Monday.

Pedantry:
The "center" of a nonspinning (Schwarzschild) black hole is a "future spacelike singularity". As the name implies, it's literally in your future, so you can't see it. And for the same reason, you can't avoid it. As for its structure, it's not a point, but a long noodle.

Spinning black holes are described by the Kerr metric, and have a ring singularity as described by this video. It's too complicated for me to comment further.

Well .... this one was oversimplified to a point where it kinda became just wrong at parts.... Especially right at the beginning at 0:43. I get it that this is an often used way of simplifying gravity. The problem is, that it's wrong while feeling intuitively correct. It leaves you thinking you got the gist of it, but you really didn't understand it at all. At least that's how I felt for a decade before someone explained it to me properly.

You see, this way of explaining it is like explaining the word "connecting" as "establishing a connection".
You're explaining gravity by saying spacetime "sags UNDERNEATH" planets and stars. But what is "underneath" or "down" or "under" without the definition of gravity in the first place? Looking at this problem another way is just watching the video at 0:43. The well forms UNDERNEATH the objects, and when things are pulled "DOWN" as if there was gravity acting, the planets would intuitively move around each other along the surface of spacetime right? See the problem? This does not explain gravity at all because we're using a gravity force that pulls downwards and the curved surface redirects that "downwards force".

The fundamental issue is that gravity - according to Einstein - is NOT A FORCE. It's a result of the geometry of spacetime and the forced movement of everything inside spacetime along the time axis. Newton's first law states that if no force is acting on a body it will move on a straight line. But a straight line on a curved surface(or 3D space or any multidimensional space) is actually not as straight as people think. These lines are called geodesics. One quick example to showcase this is looking at the path an airplane takes when it flies straight over the curved surface of earth. But when you show that path on a flattened map, it seems curved. Now let two planes start parallel to each other flying straight, on their respective geodesics, and they will fly toward each other. There was no force that pulled them together, just curved geometry. This is exactly what happens in spacetime, we move along spacetime on geodesics even when we're standing still because we are always moving along the time axis. That's why masses are "pulled" together and will end up colliding if you DON'T apply a force to keep their centers of mass at a constant distance to each other. That force is the force we feels as "gravity". (You can look up centrifugal vs centripetal force which is more of the same thing)

I hope I've helped some person on earth really understanding the gist of what gravity is.

Something really interesting that wasn’t touched on is the Event Horizon isn’t a physical barrier or location like the surface of a balloon, it’s just the moment at which the escape velocity becomes faster than the speed of light, therefore nothing can ever possibly escape. As in the video, you wouldn’t even realize you’d crossed it, the void of the black hole would just creep up around you continuously. Think of it like a whirlpool, there’s no “outer edge” to the whirlpool, the suction just gets faster and stronger until you pass a point where you can’t escape.

Meanwhile inside the black hole:
Lifeform scientists inside the black hole: "We theorise the light space exists but currently can't determine why they keep dumping their universe into our singularity."
So fascinating that the concept behind how a blackhole looks came from a movie.

About hawking radiation. If it were made of small pairs of elementary particles right at the event horizon, that raises so many questions. Does the pair come from the quantum field, or from the black hole? If it comes from the field, shouldn't the infalling particle add to the mass of the black hole? If it comes from the black hole, why does the outgoing particle have enough energy to escape? If it can, shouldn't that be so much energy that it would be detectable to us? In a rotating black hole, wouldn't the outgoing particle be confined into orbit by the ergosphere and collisions with everything in it?

This analogy wasn't devised as a particularly accurate way of explaining hawking radiation, but rather as something that was intuitable by a public audience more easily. But once you look past the surface, there are too many holes in that explanation. So let's go through these questions and see if it takes us to a more accurate explanation.


Does the pair come from the quantum field, or from the black hole?
Both. See, normally a quantum field is sort of "bubbling" in every little spot, described by a wave state equation, and each little spot hovers around, but is never quite 0. You can imagine this as a bunch of sine waves in a tube phase shifted randomly from each other. Sometimes they combine to form a loud sound, but mostly just cancel out. However, in the presence of a black hole, there is a border past which the peak of that combined wave is the same energy or higher than the energy of a photon. You can think of this like being in a wave pool with a giant wall in the middle. On the outside of that wall, everything is normal and the water is mostly still. On the inside though, all the waves travel out to the wall, where they collide with it, and can even bounce back and affect all the incoming waves. If the waves splash high enough, they can even get over the wall. In the same way, if the wave functions interfere with each other in an extreme enough manor, the combined wave manifests as a photon, and can leave if it goes off in the right direction. Hawking radiation is basically all photons, though there are some incredibly rare outliers.
The quantum field provides the wave functions. The black hole provides the intense gravitational energy density to affect those wave functions. When a photon escapes, it's the black hole's gravity that is the source of energy, and that gravity comes from its mass. So whenever that energy manifests as a photon, that mass is the ultimate source of that photon, and it decreases very slightly.

If it comes from the field, shouldn't the infalling particle add to the mass of the black hole?
If the photon falls back into the black hole, since it manifested using the black hole as energy, it would simply reclaim what it lost.

If it comes from the black hole, why does the outgoing particle have enough energy to escape?
This depends on where it actually appeared. If, like in the previous explanation, it happened at the border of the event horizon, then it's super unlikely that it would escape. But most of the photons don't actually come from there. They come from the border we talked about, which is a few times further out than the event horizon. That is the furthest point at which they can manifest, and it's there best chance to escape because there are more possible paths they can take from that point that lead outward.

If it can, shouldn't that be so much energy that it would be detectable to us?
A lot of the photons actually do escape. But on their way out, they're fighting some very extreme gravity, and so undergo what we call gravitational redshifting. The redshifting in this case is so much that they turn into extreme radio waves. So low energy that current technology can't detect them.

In a rotating black hole, wouldn't the outgoing particle be confined into orbit by the ergosphere and collisions with everything in it?
There are actually many paths that take the outgoing photon into an orbit around a region called the photon sphere, and those paths are more accessible if your path is skewed by the ergosphere. However, these orbits aren't very stable. Just a tad too far out, and it escapes. A tad too far in, and it falls back to the black hole. The chances of landing in a metastable orbit are ultimately no different whether or black hole is spinning or not.

On the topic of time. I don't see this being possible. We are only basing this on what we can see and how light is affected by gravity. Light isn't time. We perceive time with not just what we see but by all of our senses. When you close your eyes and plug your ears time doesn't stop for us. If it was possible to enter a black hole, stick around for a few hours, then exit back out then we won't see anything different and either whoever enters and exits the black whole would change and neither would whoever hangs around the outside.

It's like looking out across the universe. The further we look out the further back in time we are looking. This doesn't mean what we are looking at is currently in that time in the past, it's just how long light took to get here.

Lets say we have two people one mile away from each other but within sight of each other. One person generates a very loud noise and the other person saw it happen. Sound travels slower than light and it reaches the second person after they saw it happen. The sound traveling didn't travel through time since it was aging just light light at the same rate, it just happened to get there in far less time. Both people received the exact same amount of time pass.

Astrophysicist here. The time travel bit inside the black hole is completely unfounded. There’s nothing to support that, and we have no reason to think that any time travel other than “normal” time travel is possible (you are traveling through time at 1 second per second right now; due to relativity, more or less than one second may pass in other places, but you would never be able to go back in time). Nothing is going to “break” the universe.

A facinating fact that unfortunately not directly mentioned in this video is that beyond the event horizon, space and time swap places. Where outside of the black hole, your so called "future light cone" will always point forwards in time, meaning that no matter where you go, you will always travel in the future, inside the black hole you will always travel towards the singularity, but you can change how fast this happens by "moving around" as stated in the video.

One black hole theory i like very much, though i cannot remember whether or not it has been disqualified, is that there is no singularity. Fermion pressure still manages to keep all fermions apart from each other, so all matter falling down that hole still hits a wall and wants to bounce back. But because the pull of gravity distorts time so much, this supernova takes forever to go boom. Problem with this theory is that we cannot test it, ever. If i remember correctly, the first black holes would observably go boom in hundreds of trillions of years. What i like about this theory, no matter whether it's still a valid candidate or long disqualified, is that it works without new magic. No string theory, no zero-division, nothing.

To our best understanding all stars are rotating. For a system of mass that is made of lots and lots of particles, it is virtually impossible to say such a mass is not rotating. Even if a single particle was rotating in a star, it will have a total spin. But when that star dies and forms a black hole, its spin becomes much faster (due to conservation of angular momentum). Therefore all black holes should be a rotating black hole, and their singularity will be a ringularity.

I actually want to believe that black holes are not black inside. They're just incredibly dense, small, maybe faint but shining little star remnants. And the black event horizon is just an astronomically huge optical illusion: Because of their enormous gravity black holes bend light so much, it no longer even shows you what's behind it or it's own back, but actually has a circular 'blind spot' that appears black because it has no light source to reflect light from anymore.

But if my theory is correct, that would mean, somewhere near event horizon we should see a small, faint ring of light emmited by what's actually inside the black hole. Unfortunately, we still don't have a telescope powerful enough to look that close.

I love this channel, but I feel like the "death by blackhole" is so much more dramatized than what it actually is. In reality you'd pass out from lack of oxygen to your brain and die from the insane stress to your body due to the immense acceleration from gravity a long long time before you were spaghettified. Objects as small as humans would not experience spaghettification until within 100s of kilometres of a singularity, as that is the only place where the tidal forces between two points at different distances from the singularity is so great. However by this point your acceleration due to gravity would be many km/s per second, which humans cannot withstand. Death by black whole would feel no different than passing out in a high-g training centrifuge, only you wouldn't wake up afterwards.

If you're lucky you'll die via a supermassive blackhole, so you may be able to cross the event horizon before dying so you'd at least get a once in a lifetime experience (literally). A smaller stellar mass black hole would kill you before you even saw the event horizon. Which is a little less interesting.

What if after a black hole's hawking radiation accelerates enough, the result would be something like the big bang? I think it would make sense, although that would mean we would have to reconsider how hawking radiation works, since our big bang created these black holes in the first place. So what if matter was actually created instead of being stolen from the black hole itself. Maybe there is actually a limit to how much matter a black hole can hold, and it creates a big bang because it could not withhold all the matter, instead of being deprived of it.


That would also be plausible because if the universe(s) keep expanding there will always be more space for the new matter, and because they keep expanding, they make this theory more plausible since once the black holes get far enough away from eachother, they lose all gravitational pull towards eachother, therefore making it seem that they dont exist. This sounds just like our universe: we only know of ONE big bang, but we cant guarantee that there were no other ones, since the light they emit would probably never reach us, making this theory possible.



Also, before the big bang, it was speculated that neither time, space or light existed, yet there are contradictions such as HD 140283 Methuselah. This means that spacetime could have existed before the big bang. Also, the concentrated mass of the big bangs dormant state before the actual explosion kinda fits the description of a singularity. Another thing i found is that there is no known trigger for the big bang, which makes no sense. How could there be a START to time if there was no time before that? Time would just never start, would it? There is no POINT in time without TIME. But with my theory, time could have never started, and it's quite possible that the trigger for the big bang was Hawking radiation.



This would mean that we would lose all grip on the concept of time and space, meaning we severely underestimated them by a long shot. This would also halfway justify (but still not explain) HD 140283 Methuselah's age, since it is thought to be older than our universe. So our universe is possibly only one of many of which were created by a black hole in the previous universe after it went through heat death, which was also created by a black hole after heat death. This could prove that even our universe is just an ever-expanding cycle which always increases exponentially in size and mass. If this theory were true, we wouldnt be able to correctly assume the start of time, or the size of space.

I love this. Some extra notes, for the sake of extra fun:

1. In an ideal black hole, you can't stay at the photon sphere to look at infinite copies of yourself, since matter cannot remain in a stable orbit at this point. Yer goin' in no matter what. The faster the black hole is rotating, the closer the photon sphere gets to the ISCO.
2. The "virtual particle" model of Hawking radiation is incorrect. Hawking himself put it out as a simplification that makes the concept easier to understand. The more accurate representation is that the event horizon cuts off vibrational modes in the quantum vacuum, which manifest as particles: mostly photons. This gives them a heat glow whose wavelength is proportional to the diameter of the event horizon.
3. There are hypotheses that infalling quantum information is preserved on the event horizon, smeared out like jam, and that it may emerge again in Hawking radiation, hopelessly scrambled. This would solve the black hole information paradox. Sadly, there is as yet no evidence to support these ideas.

Thumbs down. When will people stop using this stupid (and false) explanation of Hawking radiation? If quantum fluctuations near the horizon caused the virtual particle pair to separate - one escaping away from the black hole and one being swallowed by it - it would actually increase the mass of the black hole, not decrease it. Because it would gain mass from the vacuum fluctuation.
The actual cause of Hawking radiation is much more complex and beautiful - A black hole acting as a literal hole in spacetime limits the modes of quantum fluctuations. That disturbance in vibrational modes in turn gives life to real particles.

This explanation of Hawking Radiation is wrong.

- First of all you'd expect number of virtual matter and antimatter particles crossing horizon to be the same. They would cancel each other out.
- Second you'd expect number of virtual particles crossing horizon to be proportional to event horizon surface area. So bigger black hole would radiate more but it's actually the opposite. Smaller black holes radiate stronger.

The way I view black holes is an ultra large nucleus of an atom with no space between electrons, all packed together. Since the electrons are impossible, it is not matter, but anti-matter. When an atom sized speck of black hole matter is completely removed and placed where a regular atom can collide with it, but the gravity is not strong enough to collapse the electrons, both are turned into energy, and resulting in a bright spark and loud crack sound. I have to imagine there's a point also where a black hole becomes so massive that the force that dictates gravity within the mass suddenly fails, exploding everything outward at the speed of light as energy. To me, this is a big bang event. The universe is both infinite in size and age. If we see most things moving away from each other, this simply means a black hole exploded many billion or even trillions of years ago, and such events would be extremely uncommon.

Information does escape though. It must. Recent work has actually shown that about halfway through the black hole's life, it's center actually becomes synonymous with its hawking radiation. Think about that. It doesn't just become identical to it, but synonymous. It tells us that our parochial concept of an unbroken spacetime fabric is inaccurate in some way. If you were to gather a black hole's hawking radiation, and crush it into it's own black hole, the two black holes would be connected as a wormhole. Halfway through the black hole's lifetime, when that switch happens, you can actually think of the hawking radiation as being wormholes tied to the center of the black hole, releasing the information within. As more of the black hole evaporates, it becomes more tied to its hawking radiation, eventually releasing all the information we thought was lost. Quanta Magazine wrote an incredible article on the path to this discovery. I highly recommend it. Just search Quanta Magazine Black Hole Information Paradox.

I'm not going to give you a dislike, because this IS what is currently believed, however, it should be noted that this is unlikely the ultimate truth.

Saying you can change space and time is like saying you can make an inch equal a foot. You can redefine an inch, but you can't change what it currently is, into something more or less, if that makes sense. It is for this reason, and many others that most scientists believe pretty much everything you said will be proven false as science marches on.

As for Black Holes, the likely reason for the perceived slowdown near the Event Horizon isn't time dilation, but the slowdown of light as it starts to become VISIBLY effected by its gravity. They are more the likely nothing more than supermassive objects, hence why White Dwarfs, then Neutron Stars, then Black Holes, all progressively massive and dense objects, are all formed the same way and by the same processes, with progressively higher extremes.

LMAO time travel paradoxes. If you look at it from a quantum level. There is no such thing. When you push something from the future into the past, it doesn't actually change time itself. It creates a whole new timeline separate from all other timelines. We still do not understand this mechanic entirely. However, there is reason to believe that the Schrodinger equation is absolutely the way things work. What can happen, does happen, even if you're not in the timeline where it is observed.

In less words, what you do when you go back in time, is enter your wave function into the existing universe. You change that universe when you enter it, and it branches away from the rest of the universe at that point.
