I refuse to believe in singularity, imho it is just error in the equation, that does not take into account the extreme conditions of severely distorted space-time in the black hole.

There's something about the current model of black holes that doesn't make sense to me. "Past the event horizon" shouldn't exist. At the event horizon, spacetime would be infinitely dilated. That is, time doesn't pass, and distance wouldn't exactly... exist. That means that... there is no space inside the event horizon. So, in our frame outside the black hole there appears to be a volume of space, but gravity has warped it such that... that volume would actually be zero. I think that "within" the accelerated frame of the black hole, singularity should absolutely fill that... volume? Lack of volume? However, there would be no "naked singularity" problem due to time dilation. You can't actually get to the event horizon, as time slows down so much that, well, eternity may not pass, but the black hole would evaporate due to hawking radiation before you touch the horizon. And it's hard to pass through the horizon if time absolutely stops progressing for you. It's like Zeno's paradox, but the next step halfway towards the target takes twice as much time as the one before it.

And then there's the radiation. I'm not yet talking about any radiation coming from the black hole, but all the radiation that would be shining in on you. As time dilates, you would get thousands, millions, billions of years of exposure every second. And gravitational blue shift would further increase the power; even the cosmic microwave background radiation would be hitting you like gamma rays. Any shielding would be absolutely obliterated. The atoms that make you up should be torn apart into a quark-gluon plasma. There would be no "you" left to cross the event horizon.

I have been waiting for this: Black holes are actually stars, that still shine and do not break any laws of the universe. In fact Black Holes still follows the rules, except at an extreme level. You can actually get out of a Black Hole, all you have to do is go faster than light and that happens almost every day. The thing about Black Holes is the fact that they have two Event Horizons, on for the moment that their gravitational pull equals the speed of light causing the apparent lack of ability of to see within and the second event horizon is the actual surface of the object within below the first event horizon. The only thing you need to know to about why Black Holes do not break the rules and still follow them is that even Black Holes die, the more energy you have the longer you last and black Holes have a lot of energy. The curvature of Black Holes cannot be infinite, and the density cannot be infinite: However the curvature can have any number of values that result from the gravitational acceleration of it's own mass to exceed the Speed of Light which may as well have an infinite number of values and the density can have any number of values that cause the fundamental forces to exceed their ability to remain separate and again the which may as well be infinite, both results give you what a Black Hole looks like but you can go even further beyond. A black Hole cannot be causally disconnect from the rest of the universe because that would mean you are no longer dealing with an object, but an intermediary phenomenon such as a Wormhole where two distinct coordinate within the universe or without the universe are connected and those two coordinated cannot interact with each other any differently than their numerical value dictates I.E. a Wormhole from Earth to the Sun won't cause the Orbit of the Earth to act like it is right next to the sun. There is a lot of things I could over with Black Holes and details I could describe to you, but I currently do not have the material at hand to create an animated slideshow to teach even the most basic of minds. A Ringularity is when the Singularity of a Black Hole is off-set from it's own center, so the Black Hole actually orbits itself: The closer the rotation is to the Speed of Light the more off-set the rotation will be, at the Speed of Light the off-sett rotation will be tangent to the Singularity I.E. surface of the second Event Horizon within the First Event Horizon, then if you exceed the Speed of Light (which can happen) the off-set rotation would be further than the surface of the second Event Horizon. Quantum Fluctuations are like the zeros and ones to a computer code: If the value equals zero because a particles has been spawned with an anti-particle that matches it then both particles annihilate each other which creates raw energy, however if the value equals one then the particle that spawns without an anti-particle that matches it goes out into space and does stuff. Black Holes are intermediary generators for these particles, or you could see them as regulators: Either way Black Holes have a ton of energy, and are very efficient with using it. Everything in the universe goes towards entropy, hence why the closer you are to total entropy the more efficient you become. That is why dead stars last longer than live stars. The bigger the star the more energy it has, the more energy it has the longer it takes to reach total entropy. That is why black holes take a long time, they have a lot of energy.

I understand that when talking about something as complex and with as many theories as black holes you kind of need to dumb it down a little bit for people to grasp the basics, but as I understand the science of this (I am a dumb person, so I can be very wrong) light is not affected by the gravity of a black hole. Light knows nothing of direction or speed and will always go straight with no mass to cause a lag on speed, so the medium it travels through is the only way to affect either of those features. Since gravity is just what we interpret spacial bending as, the idea of black holes affecting light any differently than any other massive space-bending object might be a little disingenuous. Even our planet's mass can affect light through the pull it has on the fabric of spacetime, it's just incredibly small and almost insignificant in comparison.

Anyway, apart from that slight clarification that gravity itself isn't a force that acts on anything and is just an effect of warped spacetime (again, I totally understand the need to limit things like this or it would be a very long and boring video), I approve. Here's a thought. Instead of Mass -> Gravity -> Slowing of time, could it be better interpreted as Mass -> Slowing of Time -> Gravity?
That is, the slowing of time around massive objects would be a byproduct of their mass (including energy), and gravity a manifestation of this non-uniform flowing of time.

In which case, a black hole would be the extreme of this, where enough mass has gathered for time to completely stop flowing. This in turn, creates the gravity well that surpasses the speed of light.

This could also be explained as part of 'The Universe is a Simulation', as a dense concentration of mass would take more time to compute, and thus have a slower flow of time.

An outside observer never sees something actually cross the event horizon and something that falls in might observe the universe "speeding up". The black hole itself is shrinking over time until it completely evaporates.

Is there a theory suggesting that nothing actually crosses the event horizon, and that whatever "falls into" the black hole actually watches the event horizon shrinking? Getting closer and closer to the centre but never crossing the horizon because it shrinks at least as fast as the observer is falling?

Black holes cannot form. Not even the GW170817 event formed one, it instead formed a hypermagnetar. If two neutron stars colliding wouldn't create a black hole, what could?

The answer is nothing could, anymore. From a gravitational frame of reference, matter would have to accelerate faster than the speed of light for a black hole to form, and we know that to be impossible.

This isn't to say that black holes do not exist, of course they do. The thing is that all black holes that exist now have always existed since the big bang; they're all primordial black holes.

Why do we think that inside of black hole is a singularity? The black hole is simply a spacetime warped to such an extend that even light cant escape it (so just as Earth's escape speed it 15 000 km/h for black hole these values exceed 300 000 km/s). If our general relativity theory breaks down when trying to explain singularity (with infinite density and no dimensions) why there's no one considering that inside is normal matter, just compressed more than in neutron star, yet still with dimensions and finite density?
If you wanna know more, PBS Space Time has a great series on this.

We know from gravitational waves that black holes merge, so since you're "sanwitched" between the two even horizons, your body must end up in at least one Black Hole within a finite amount of time. How can you determine which black hole swallows you if in the first system the external observer would have never seen you fall through?
